html: As a transition to Jehovah’s servant speaking (vv 4-11), Jehovah again appears as the maker of heaven and earth—thereby lending the servant his authority—only this time asserting his destructive, not creative power. A return to chaos follows his people’s apostasy (vv 1-2): sea and rivers become desert (Isaiah 19:5-7; 42:15), drought conditions prevail (Isaiah 33:9; 64:10), and the heavens are darkened (Isaiah 8:22; 59:9-10). For the son/servant category, on the other hand, Sea and River—the king of Assyria/Babylon—dry up in order to facilitate its new exodus to Zion (Isaiah 11:15-16; 51:10-11).
